G.L. c. 218, \u00a719.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19 and G.L. c. 212, §3, as the amount in controversy does not exceed $25,000 and the acts giving rise to this complaint occurred within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a73.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19 and G.L. c. 212, §3, as the amount in controversy does not exceed $25,000 and the acts giving rise to this complaint occurred within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a78.proposition: Venue is proper in the Cambridge Division of the District Court Department under G.L. c. 223, §8, because the property at issue is located in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 186.proposition: The tenancy has at all relevant times been governed by G.L. c. 186 and Massachusetts common law.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 186, §14, a landlord may not directly or indirectly interfere with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of leased premises.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a715F.proposition: Plaintiff has not waived any rights to quiet enjoyment under the lease; any attempt at waiver would be void as against public policy under G.L. c. 186, §15F.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease under Massachusetts law.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly assumes and applies an implied covenant (or warranty) of quiet enjoyment in these leases, but it does not expressly state that such a covenant is implied in every residential lease under Massachusetts law. The court focuses on whether the landlords’ conduct breached an "implied covenant of quiet enjoyment" and caused constructive eviction, not on the broader, categorical proposition about all residential leases. Thus it is consistent with, but not clear authority for, the universal statement in the proposition.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: The judge found that the tenants were "very substantially deprived" of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises "for a substantial time" (emphasis original). He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge). The landlords argue that they did not violate the tenants’ implied covenant of quiet enjoyment because they are not chargeable with the noise from the lounge.

Winthrop Corp. v. Lowenthal, 29 Mass. Ap.raw_text: Winthrop Corp. v. Lowenthal, 29 Mass. App. Ct. 180 (1990)
Winthrop Corp. v. Lowenthal, 29 Mass. Ap.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease under Massachusetts law.
Winthrop Corp. v. Lowenthal, 29 Mass. Ap.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns arbitration, attorney’s fees, fraud on the court, and Rule 60(b) relief; it does not involve landlord–tenant law, residential leases, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Nowhere does the court discuss or imply that a covenant of quiet enjoyment is included in every residential lease or any lease at all. Therefore, this case cannot be proper authority for the stated proposition.
Winthrop Corp. v. Lowenthal, 29 Mass. Ap.relevant_excerpt: Here, the source of the award of legal fees is the provision in the contract between Winthrop and Lowenthal stating that the prevailing party in any action or proceeding “shall be entitled to recover its costs and reasonable attorney’s fees” (emphasis added). In order to consider whether Mr. Singer’s conduct constituted fraud on the court, we first determine if he was required to disclose the existence of the contingent fee agreement.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Breach occurs when the landlord’s actions, or those under his control, substantially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court squarely discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and explains that liability turns on the landlord’s conduct where the ‘natural and probable consequence’ is interruption of the tenant’s rights, not on subjective intent. It further holds that Gem is liable because it violated its duty to maintain sanitary conditions and thereby permitted repeated flooding that interfered with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. This aligns with the proposition that a breach occurs when the landlord’s actions or omissions substantially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, including through conditions caused by persons ostensibly beyond the landlord’s control but within its legal responsibility.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Although early cases applying the covenant of quiet enjoyment required intent on the part of the landlord… more recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Lowell Housing Authority v. Save-More Di.raw_text: Lowell Housing Authority v. Save-More Discount House, 346 Mass. 426 (1963)
Lowell Housing Authority v. Save-More Di.proposition: A landlord need not act with intent; negligent or foreseeable interference may suffice.
Lowell Housing Authority v. Save-More Di.case_name: Lowell Housing Authority v. Save-Mor Furniture Stores, Inc.
Lowell Housing Authority v. Save-More Di.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a landlord’s right to recover the fair rental value from a tenant at sufferance after an eminent domain taking. It does not discuss any requirement of intent, negligence, or foreseeability as elements of liability; rather, liability turns on status as tenant at sufferance and control/detaining of the premises under the statute. Thus, it does not support the proposition that negligent or foreseeable interference (as opposed to intentional conduct) is sufficient for landlord liability in a tort or interference context.
Lowell Housing Authority v. Save-More Di.relevant_excerpt: “The basis of liability for use and occupation consists in the control over the premises which effectively deprives the new owner of the use of the property. … In our opinion the judge warrantably concluded from the auditor’s report that Save-Mor’s permission to Smith to use the area of the second floor … was an exercise of dominion over its use and constituted a detaining of the area by Save-Mor within the meaning of the statute.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Sustained noise, vibrations, and dust caused by construction under the landlord’s control constitute substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The case concerns criminal drug activity in common areas and the landlord’s failure to take security measures; it does not involve construction, nor noise, vibration, or dust. The court’s discussion of breach of quiet enjoyment is framed around the landlord permitting criminal activity by third parties to continue, not around construction-related disturbances. Therefore, this opinion does not provide authority for the proposition that sustained construction noise, vibrations, and dust under the landlord’s control constitute substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Sustained noise, vibrations, and dust caused by construction under the landlord’s control constitute substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion is about whether a statutory lead paint violation, by itself, constitutes a breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment and holds that at least negligent conduct with notice is required. It does not address noise, vibrations, dust, construction activities, or what constitutes substantial interference from such conditions. Therefore it provides no authority on the proposition concerning sustained construction-related disturbances under a landlord’s control.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).proposition: The covenant protects against disturbances that make the premises unsuitable for the purposes for which they were rented.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).support_reasoning: This decision concerns a landlord-tenant dispute and discusses breach of the implied warranty of habitability, breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, and c. 93A, but the quoted portion of the opinion never defines or explains the scope of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The discussion of damages focuses on warranty-of-habitability and c. 93A theories, not on what kinds of disturbances render premises unsuitable under the covenant. Thus, the case as presented does not affirm the specific proposition about the covenant protecting against disturbances making the premises unsuitable for the rented purpose.

Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mas.raw_text: Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375 (1942)
Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mas.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that even reasonable renovation hours may still violate the covenant when the intrusion materially impairs habitability or ordinary comfort.
Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mas.support_reasoning: The case deals with constructive eviction caused by smoke, soot, and fumes from an oil burner, not with renovation work or the reasonableness of renovation hours. The court focuses on whether the landlord’s acts (and failure to remedy conditions) materially deprived the tenant of use and enjoyment, but says nothing about permissible or reasonable hours of construction or renovation. Thus it supports the broader principle that serious interference with habitability can amount to constructive eviction, but not the specific proposition about renovation hours violating a covenant.
Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The defence of eviction, actual or constructive, is based upon a failure of consideration, or a breach, whether of commission or omission, of a covenant of the lease so material as to excuse the tenant from performing. … [I]f the landlord’s acts necessarily deprive the tenant permanently or for a substantial time of the enjoyment of the property it can hardly be material with what intention the landlord acts.”
